Guilt, guilt, bat eyelashes, bat eyelashes, etc.

Long time viewers will know we&#39;ve had a lot of 
fun here at the Zero Punctuation combination

waterslide park sewage treatment facility 
with the running gag that virtually every

arty indie game is basically about a small 
child being lost in a scary world. Probably

because they&#39;re frequently made by tech 
nerds new to the industry having to face

the fact that it might finally be time to get 
a real job and figure out how to do their own

laundry. Which also explains why the games 
are usually highly unsubtle metaphors for

something from the standard list of tech nerd 
mental health issues: anxiety, depression,

isolation, the fact that nice girls don&#39;t want 
to touch them. In the past I&#39;ve occasionally

stretched the criteria for small child scary 
world to include indie games like Bastion,

Braid and Ori and the Blind Forest, in order 
to continue claiming to be right in my adorably

small minded way, but absolutely no stretching is 
necessary for this week&#39;s subject, oh dear me no.

Little Nightmares wears small child scary world 
like a set of custom fit pyjamas, throws a big

comfortable duvet of oppressive atmosphere over 
itself and goes to sleep. It uses all the tropes,

even the really on the nose ones like &quot;main 
character wears a hooded coat&quot; and &quot;soundtrack

featuring sad children singing like the evil 
landlord just sold all their gruel vouchers.&quot;

I might go as far to say that it officially takes 
Limbo&#39;s crown as the ur-example of small child

scary world, since Limbo&#39;s pseudo-sequel Inside 
kind of gave it up when it transitioned from

small child scary world to GIBBER GIBBER NONSENSE 
NONSENSE WEETABIX WITH LEGS. Little Nightmares 2,

I should say, which is the new one, but in 
general terms the two games don&#39;t differ

much and I never reviewed the first because, I 
dunno, let&#39;s say a zeppelin crashed into my house,

so might as well lump &#39;em together. They&#39;re both 
extremely creepy games about a tiny child with a

big head navigating a sequence of horror 
set pieces and blatantly unfair traps as

they continually physics platform their way in a 
rightward direction in the classic Limbo style,

all drenched in an oppressive atmosphere of thick, 
slimy dread where anything might leap out and

bite you off at the ankles at any moment, like a 
shark-infested gravy boat. Only real difference

is that 2 is a prequel to 1, establishing 
the long-speculated-on backstory of the main

character&#39;s raincoat. Spoiler alert: she found it 
in a puddle. Whoops, better update the wiki.

Which should more or less indicate that this 
isn&#39;t a game whose appeal hinges on the plot.

There isn&#39;t much of one besides &quot;small child wants 
something that for whatever reason is really far

off to the right somewhere.&quot; There are little 
nuggets of background storytelling establishing

some things about the setting but raise further 
questions - why are the funny noises coming out

of the TV, why are all the adults hostile and 
look like characters from an Eastern European

stop motion animated film apparently specifically 
designed to traumatize poorly supervised

children - but the thing is, the point of playing 
the game is not to resolve its plot, but to exist

within that world for a while and drink in its 
atmosphere, which is rather effectively and

convincingly like that of a nightmare. There you 
go, that&#39;s the plot. It&#39;s a nightmare. Even gave

it away in the title. It&#39;s all a nightmare and it 
doesn&#39;t have to make sense. So don&#39;t worry so much

about that wiki after all. In terms of building 
that experience, Little Nightmares rarely puts a

foot wrong. It takes everyday mundane settings and 
people and soaks them in liquid grotesque until

they&#39;re all sodden and bloated like an Edvard 
Munch painting that was hung over a steam vent.

The environments are beautifully realised, 
the monstrous adults all look like papier

mache projects your kids brought home from 
school and that you have to pretend are cute,

and all the little details are spot on, from the 
sound of their laboured breathing to the way they

jerkily animate like they just drank ten pints and 
are trying to remember which way&#39;s the floor and

which way&#39;s the ceiling. And the animation of 
the main character, too, the way they scamper

along with their head bowed like they&#39;re trying to 
get through a public park at night without being

noticed by the scary teenagers. So on the whole 
the setting and atmosphere hit the mark like a

boxer who hates people named mark. Fuck you, 
I had writer&#39;s block. In fact one might call

Little Nightmares a game that&#39;s 100% atmosphere 
because the moment you try to engage with it on

a story or gameplay level then it sort of stares 
blankly at you for a moment before a sweaty fat

man chases you into a mousehole again. As I said, 
the challenge aspect of the game is basically a

sequence of traps where the objective is generally 
&quot;make exactly the right movements or die and start

again.&quot; Which in the abstract is about as fun 
as playing Operation in a Parkinson&#39;s ward.

There are chasey bits where the monster catches 
up and stuffs you into a pita bread if you&#39;re not

immediately sprinting in the right direction 
when it starts. There are combatty bits where

you have to swing a melee weapon at precisely 
the moment an enemy is pouncing or get your

head caved in on a floorboard, and stealthy bits 
where you get spotted and eaten if you so much as

startle a flatulent aphid. Which leads to some 
moments having to be replayed and replayed and

dread gives way to boredom gives way to anger 
gives way to quitting gives way to the right

at a mini-roundabout. I don&#39;t know how one fixes 
this, it&#39;s the classic horror game paradox: the

threat of sudden death is necessary for creating 
the feel of being a little ant postman trying to

deliver mail to Mrs. Trapdoor Spider&#39;s house, but 
the moment that sudden death actually happens all

the tension disappears, and each subsequent death 
as you struggle to get past the challenge is like

the game continuing to stab an already stabbed 
balloon. I suppose ideally you&#39;d want to design it

so the player escapes by the skin of their teeth 
each time and that&#39;s a tough balance because some

players have slower reflexes or are trying to 
play while hiding behind the sofa cushions.

Of course, one thing that might help is to 
not have us wrestle with the physics engine

the whole way through. Why&#39;d you have to add the 
third dimension to the keep-pressing-right Limbo

formula? Uh oh, three dimensional movement plus 
platforming plus fixed cameras equals the square

root of a faceful of piss. There&#39;s a bit where 
you have to jump off a ladder onto a rope that

dangles from above and there&#39;s absolutely no frame 
of reference for where that rope is, precisely,

and you can only blindly hope it&#39;s positioned so 
that a jump straight off the ladder will hit it.

Which it turns out it wasn&#39;t if you&#39;ve moved an 
inch or two to the left. And then when you&#39;re on

the rope, whether you&#39;re swinging towards the 
next ledge or skull fracture city is a matter

the game might as well be deciding with a ouija 
board. For me, Little Nightmares shows a stark

contrast. Much of its imagery and set pieces will 
come back to you, especially if you eat petrol

station sausage rolls just before going to bed, 
but they&#39;re the only things that will because the

gameplay&#39;s as deep as a very disappointing 
pie. I had writer&#39;s block again, fuck you.
